title: Eyeing Presidential Bid, Michael Bloomberg Makes Big Television-Ad Buys
summary: Former New York City mayor books about $37 million in advertising in dozens of markets. Billionaire Michael Bloomberg has begun buying a large amount of television advertising time for next week in another sign he may be preparing to announce a Democratic presidential bid.

title: The Best-Managed Companies of 2019
summary: Resume Subscription. America's best-run companies today include some of the nation's oldest corporate giants and many of its most nimble technology firms.

title: Bolton Says White House Blocked Access to Twitter Account
summary: President Trump denies allegation regarding former national security adviser's handle. WASHINGTON-Former National Security Adviser John Bolton broke his silence on Friday with a claim that the White House blocked access to his Twitter account in the months since he departed the Trump administration, suggesting he was locked out over fear of what he might say.

title: WeWork Turns to Maurice Lévy for Help Rebuilding Brand
summary: Mr. Lévy, who turned Publicis into global ad giant, will serve as the embattled startup's interim chief marketing officer. Beleaguered office-space startup WeWork has tapped well-known ad man Maurice Lévy to be interim chief marketing officer, as the company faces an uphill battle to repair its image after its spectacular fall from grace.

title: Trump Calls Hong Kong Protests 'Complicating Factor' in Trade Talks
summary: President won't say if he would sign bill passed by Congress supporting protesters. President Trump called antigovernment protests in Hong Kong a "complicating factor" in his bid for an elusive trade deal with China and didn't say whether he would sign a bill passed by Congress supporting the protesters.

title: 'The Puritans' and 'The Trials of Thomas Morton' Review: Working for a Better World
summary: David D. Hall's magisterial history follows a controversial movement as it emerged in the Old World and began to shape the New.. The debate about the meaning of early American history has become a debate about the meaning of America itself. Over the past few months, for instance, the New York Times's "1619" project has attempted to re-center the American story around the moment when, 400 years ago last August, more than 20 kidnapped Africans were sold to colonists in Virginia.

title: Former Transportation Executive Convicted In Nuclear-Energy Bribery Case
summary: Mark Lambert, the former president of Transportation Logistics Inc., was found guilty of participating in a scheme to bribe a Russian official, prosecutors said. The former president of a Maryland transportation company was found guilty of participating in a scheme to bribe a unit of a Russian nuclear energy company, the Justice Department said Friday.

title: Mayor Pete's South Bend Record
summary: The issue isn't that his city is small. It's how he performed as a leader.. Pete Buttigieg is rising in the Democratic presidential polls on his rhetorical gifts, distinctive resumé and fund-raising prowess. But the 37-year-old mayor of South Bend, Indiana, has so far largely received a pass on his government record from the press and even other Democrats. That isn't likely to continue, and a good place to start is his trouble controlling violent crime.

title: Elizabeth Warren Is Right
summary: Her rival Bernie Sanders declines to call Nicolás Maduro a dictator.. Elizabeth Warren is a progressive hero, so it's notable when she takes a position that is attacked on the left. A case in point is Venezuela, where the Senator has more or less supported Donald Trump's policy. In a podcast clip from earlier this year that's getting second life on the left, Ms. Warren calls Venezuela's Nicolás Maduro "obviously a dictator" who's putting people through "a nightmare."

title: The Mythology of Voter Suppression
summary: Democrats cling to the falsehood despite the election turnout facts.. Democrats picked up 40 House seats and nine governorships last year. We'd call that a good year. Yet during the debate Wednesday night the presidential candidates continue to flog the falsehood that Republicans stole the 2018 Georgia Governor's race and are generally stifling voter turnout.

title: Winning Was Trump's High Crime and Misdemeanor
summary: His conflict with his staff over Ukraine was nothing compared with Obama's decision to leave Iraq.. When I don't get the feeling Adam Schiff is secretly working for the Russians, I get the feeling he's secretly working for Donald Trump. The latter feeling predominated during two weeks of impeachment hearings. The case, which doesn't strike me as strong, should be that Mr. Trump withheld, or threatened to withhold, congressionally mandated military aid for Ukraine for an illegal purpose. But the witnesses who were supposed to be harmful to Mr. Trump weren't. They failed to establish, or even argue, that Mr. Trump's concern with the Biden role in Ukraine, or Ukraine's role in the 2016 election, was illegitimate.

title: California's Spending Boom Masks a Spate of Problems
summary: Politicians are rolling in tax revenue, but they can't seem to solve basic issues like housing and energy.. This should be the best of times in California. A vigorous national economy is providing record numbers of jobs and robust growth in tax revenue. But far from flourishing, California is increasingly beset by social and economic problems, from homeless encampments to rubbish-strewn streets to blackouts.

title: The Child-Rearing Wisdom of 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'
summary: He taught a generation of parents how to connect with their kids' emotions. Science has caught up.. When parents ask me for advice on interacting with their young children, I prescribe "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood." They watch all the reruns they can find.

title: Notable & Quotable: Agencies
summary: 'Aggressively straying from our mission . . . provides potentially potent ammunition' for critics.. From a Nov. 14 speech by Jay Clayton, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission:

title: 'The Missing Pages' Review: From Genocide to Justice
summary: In 2010, the Armenian Church sued the Getty Museum for return of a medieval religious relic.. Illuminatedmanuscripts, copied by hand and painstakingly adorned with vibrant colors and gold leaf, predate by centuries Gutenberg's Bible, printed around 1450 using movable metal type. While such manuscripts are acquired by museums for their purely artistic merits, they began as venerated spiritual objects intended for ceremonial use, not at all intended as art in the modern sense. Some originated in cultures still active today, prompting the question: Is it possible to understand a religious relic simply as art, removed from its history and the culture that made it? This perilous fault line-between the cosmopolitan enjoyment of art objects removed from their histories and their use by cultures still living those histories-provides the compelling tension of Heghnar Zeitlian Watenpaugh's "The Missing Pages: The Modern Life of a Medieval Manuscript From Genocide to Justice."

title: Boost U.S. Innovation and Manufacturing
summary: Our national policy is to pay lip service to this sector while ignoring how discouraging our national policy is toward manufacturing and the skills it takes to create an actual product.. It is about time someone talked about innovation in the U.S. ("Innovation Should Be Made in the U.S.A.," Review, Nov. 16). But the problem actually runs deeper. As a small manufacturer, I have been hearing for years about comparative advantage from economists, but in truth the comparative advantage is an authoritarian nation with a mercantilist industrial policy. Further, politicians encourage manufacturers to go offshore by having punitive, rather than common-sense, regulations in the areas of tort, the EPA, OSHA, ICE and the IRS. Our national policy is to pay lip service to this sector while ignoring how discouraging our national policy is toward manufacturing and the skills it takes to create an actual product. It is all truly discouraging.

title: We Shun Pro-Life AGs Because Roe Is the Law
summary: The Constitution is still the law of the land in all 50 states, and Roe was ruled constitutional in 1973. Democrats and Republicans alike agree that the role of a state attorney general is to uphold the rule of law.. Your Nov. 19 editorial ("Purging the Pro-Lifers") disapproves of the Democratic Attorneys General Association's (DAGA) decision to only endorse pro-choice attorney general candidates. Your editorial not only misreads the direction the country is going, but it ignores the rule of law-Roe v. Wade is settled law.

title: Who Will Build the Bridges When Everyone Gets an A Grade?
summary: At the end of my 37 years of teaching at a large Midwestern university I was accused in 2012-13 of "too harsh grading" of my geology students, thus "causing damage to the department.". Regarding the letters "Adjusting and Lowering College Standards" (Nov. 15): At the end of my 37 years of teaching at a large Midwestern university I was accused in 2012-13 of "too harsh grading" of my geology students, thus "causing damage to the department." The chair of my department took the liberty of voiding my final course grades for an entire class of about 50 students officially submitted at the end of the semester to the registrar's office and arbitrarily raising the grades by one point for the entire class. He thus eliminated all failing grades and raised grades for students he never interacted with, all with the provost's approval.

title: U.S. Blacklists Iran's Minister of Information and Communications Technology
summary: The designation comes in the wake of blocked internet access following antiregime protests in the country. The U.S. blacklisted Iran's minister of information and communications technology for an alleged role in internet censorship in the wake of antiregime protests in the country, the U.S. Treasury Department said Friday.

title: Book Review: A Who's Who of the Air
summary: Carel Fabritius's celebrated goldﬁnch is near-perfect: alive, ready to fly, only to be caught by its tether.. Lithography and, later, photographic reproduction made the art of ornithology accessible-one might even say possible. Before the advent of photography, most portrayals of actively moving and especially flying birds were unconvincing. Still, "The Art of the Bird: The History of Ornithological Art Through Forty Artists" (Chicago, 224 pages, $35), by Roger J. Lederer, begins by bringing to light masterworks from an earlier era when the detailed study of birds was an obscure and difficult pursuit.

title: 'The Greatest Upset Never Seen' Review: David and Goliath: A Courtside View
summary: Before facing the No. 1 Virginia Cavaliers, the Silverswords had lost to a small-college team with a 5-9 record.. When THE Virginia Cavaliers played in Honolulu on Dec. 23, 1982, they were the No. 1-ranked team in college basketball and led by 7-foot-4 center Ralph Sampson, the nation's top player. Their opponent was Chaminade University, a Catholic school with 800 undergraduates whose basketball team consisted mostly of residents of Hawaii.

title: 'The Golden Thread' Review: The Warp and Woof of History
summary: From birth to death, fabric is an essential element of our lives.. A couple of months ago I was turned away from a London club. "I'm sorry, madam, but jeans are not permitted in the dining room," said the deeply embarrassed 20-something porter who, I am willing to bet, wears nothing but denim on his days off. This has now happened to me often enough that I keep a mental tally of the places where, despite my being a middle-aged woman in mom jeans, my entrance has been refused based not on my not being chic enough-which would certainly be true-but on my wearing a certain kind of ubiquitous blue cotton trousers.

title: What to Give: Books on Photography
summary: William Meyers on books featuring the work of Sheron Rupp, Jason Eskenazi and Robert Adams.. The great pleasure in Sheron Rupp's "Taken From Memory" (Kehrer Verlag, 112 pages, $50) is the photographer's evident affection for her subjects, mostly country people in country places: Elkins, Ark.; Shawnee, Ohio; Belt Creek, Mont.; Pineville, Ky. Ms. Rupp does not come among them as a stranger; there is no condescension to their poverty, no sense of their being other. And the colors are as glorious as a prize-winning quilt. The subject of "Ona, Greensboro Bend, Vermont" (1990) sits with her head on her hand and smiles a wry smile. Ten very blond people, most of them children, most of them looking at Polaroid prints, crowd the frame of "Bayside, Ontario, Canada" (1995). The white-haired woman in "Logan, Ohio" (1985) stops hanging her wash to face the camera.

title: 'Out Loud' Review: The Barefoot Boy
summary: One of America's leading proponents of modern dance on his gayness and self-regard, in language that is loud, clear, and not shy of four-letter words.. 'Out Loud,' the title of Mark Morris's memoir, is, of course, a pointed play on "Out and Loud." In this free-wheeling, loose-limbed, highly spirited book, one of our leading proponents of modern dance candidly stresses his gayness and self-regard in language that is loud, clear and not shy of four-letter words.

title: 'Still Here' Review: The Show-Stopper
summary: Elaine Stritch knew how to bring down the house with a song, but never learned how to share the stage.. I went to see "Company" not long after its Broadway opening, in April 1970; all I can remember of it, these many years later, is Elaine Stritch as the acidulous, boozy Joanne, singing "The Ladies Who Lunch" in that voice that one critic likened to "a car shifting gears without the clutch." I didn't understand the show, which I thought cold, or even the number, which I found obscurely threatening. How could I? I was 13 years old, and "Company," with a book by George Furth and music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, was one of the first musicals written entirely for adults-and cynical adults at that. But Stritch made an impression on me that has never faded.

title: U.S. Stocks Rise as China Calls for Better Communication
summary: President Xi Jinping says China has been 'working actively' to avoid a trade war. U.S. stocks rose Friday after Chinese President Xi Jinping called for Beijing and Washington to strengthen communications, but still lost ground for the week.

title: Macy's, Coty, American Express: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose shares moved on the week's news. Macy's Inc.

title: Regulator to Rehear Disciplinary Case Due to Potential Conflict
summary: Officer who presided over case against brokerage executive was also interviewing for a job with the enforcement unit. A Wall Street regulator, in a highly unusual step, is rehearing a case barring a former brokerage executive from the business because of an undisclosed conflict involving the case's hearing officer.

title: Ex-CIA Officer Sentenced to 19 Years for Efforts to Supply China With Classified Data
summary: Jerry Chun Shing Lee admitted to communicating with, preparing documents for Chinese spy agency. ALEXANDRIA, Va.-A former CIA officer was sentenced to 19 years in prison Friday for conspiring to provide classified information to China, the latest U.S. intelligence officer to be sentenced for efforts to give secrets to China.

title: Trump Warns of Dangers in Banning Vape Flavors
summary: In meeting with industry leaders, president signals White House rethinking plan to pull sweet and fruity e-cigarette flavors. White House support for a ban on sweet and fruity e-cigarettes appeared to be softening, as President Trump said the market prohibition could have dangerous consequences.

title: 'Betrayal in Berlin' and 'Checkpoint Charlie' Review: Tales of Two Cities
summary: In one of the most audacious and successful spy operations of the Cold War, the U.S. and U.K. tunneled a quarter-mile beneath Berlin into Soviet territory.. Almost exactly 30 years ago, as we have been reminded in recent weeks by a flurry of articles and tweets, broadcasts, podcasts and documentaries, the wall dividing Berlin began to come down. Sometimes an anniversary can lack relevance or feel overblown, but not this one. The fall of the Berlin Wall was a pivotal moment in 20th-century history, but it has a renewed importance today. We live in an age of walls, yet the most iconic wall in living memory remains the one that split Berlin between 1961 and 1989. But how did Germany get to this point, and what was it like to live in the shadow of this strange, minatory structure?

title: How Washington Normally Treats Whistleblowers
summary: Plus, the Bidens can still help Burisma.. The popularity of impeachment may have peaked, but give House Democrats credit. They persuaded nearly half the country that the President should be removed from office for asking Ukraine to examine a deal which any reasonable person would agree deserves examination.

title: Smucker Lowers Sales Outlook
summary: Company now sees net sales falling 3% this fiscal year. J.M. Smucker Co. said sales in its pet business are dragging, a fresh sign of trouble in a unit the food maker was counting on to help make up for slack packaged-foods demand.

title: Tesla Unveiled a Bulletproof Pickup. Then the Window Broke.
summary: Elon Musk touted the vehicle's toughness, but a demonstration Thursday highlighted challenges it could face on the market. Elon Musk embraced unorthodox designs for Tesla Inc.'s all-electric pickup to wow truck buyers and help differentiate it from popular gasoline-powered models that he knocked as boring look-alikes.

title: Jake Burton Carpenter Turned Snow Surfing Into a Business, Sport
summary: Nearly eight million people now snowboard in the U.S.-about a third of them ride a Burton board. Jake Burton Carpenter went to college as an aspiring ski racer but could never shake his teenage obsession with a $10 monoski called the Snurfer. He believed at an early age that the board, which allowed people to surf snow, could be a sport and big business.

title: Investors Spurn Riskiest Corporate Bonds
summary: Triple-C bonds have fared particularly poorly of late, even as investors show healthy appetite for other risky assets. Investors are demanding more compensation to hold the lowest-rated tier of U.S. corporate bonds than at any time in more than three years, highlighting a selloff that some have taken as a warning signal for other riskier assets.

title: U.S. Begins Transporting Asylum-Seeking Migrants in Arizona to Texas
summary: People crossing the southern border hadn't been sent back across to await asylum hearings, drawing more migrants to the area south of Tucson. U.S. Customs and Border Protection will begin busing asylum-seeking migrants who cross the U.S. southern border in Arizona to Texas, to then be returned to Mexico to await their asylum hearings, a U.S. government official said.

title: Canada Rejects Calls for Legislation to End Railway Strike
summary: Government says the quickest way to resolve the strike, in its fourth day, is through collective bargaining, as work stoppage disrupts economy. OTTAWA-Canada brushed off demands from business groups and regional political leaders to introduce legislation to end a labor dispute between Canadian National Railway Co. and over 3,000 unionized employees that is disrupting the economy.

title: Latina Women to Lose Out on More Than $1 Million Over Their Careers
summary: Economic effect of gender wage disparity on a Latina woman's career is 'pretty unrecoverable,' expert says. Latina women earn 46% less than white men and 31% less than white women, the worst gender wage gap for any group of minority women, according to 2019 data.

title: Shale Drillers' Latest Problems: Hog Manure and Chicken Guts
summary: New facilities that turn livestock, poultry waste into biogas are creating headwind for shale gas producers who are dialing back production. It isn't just Appalachian shale drillers that are swamping the natural-gas market. Chicken slaughterhouses, pig farms, expired yogurt and leftover bits from your last meal are contributing to the glut.

title: House Judiciary Panel Awaits Impeachment Report
summary: Panel begins preparing for initial hearing on what actions count as high crimes and misdemeanors; Trump says he welcomes Senate trial. WASHINGTON-Impeachment proceedings now move to a new stage as scheduled public hearings are over and the House Intelligence Committee will write a report about President Trump pressing Ukraine to investigate his political rivals that will be presented to the House Judiciary Committee to weigh articles of impeachment.

title: A 'Requiem' to Remember
summary: Teodor Currentzis, leading his musicAeterna orchestra and chorus in their North American debut, delivered a revelatory performance of Verdi's work.. New York

title: Holiday Ad Creep Comes to Influencer Marketing
summary: Brands want more holiday content from influencers, and sooner. Brands are pushing influencers to show their holiday spirit sooner and more often.

title: Supreme Court to Decide Case of Muslims Placed on No-Fly List
summary: Four men claim they deserve money damages for being improperly placed on the list. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether four Muslim men can seek monetary damages from FBI agents who they claim put them on the no-fly list because they wouldn't serve as informers against other Muslims.

title: Smucker Can't Talk Its Way Out of This Jam
summary: Repeated guidance cuts and inconsistent comments on the outlook for its pet-food brands are giving J.M. Smucker a credibility problem. J.M. Smucker is developing a credibility problem with investors.

title: Turning a List Into a Book
summary: How to make the most of a tired journalistic genre..

title: A Tale of Man as an Island
summary: Daniel Defoe's 'Robinson Crusoe' is a monument to man's ingenuity and resilience-and a rebuke to human vanity..

title: After Indictment, Frustrations With Israeli Leader Grow in Likud Party
summary: Prime minister's best chance to fight the corruption charges is to remain in control of the party and force a third election. TEL AVIV-Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing new political and legal challenges after being indicted on corruption charges, as Israel moves toward a likely third election in a year.

title: Want to Help a Woman of Color in Her Career? Expose Her to New Experiences
summary: New opportunities are about the chance to learn, Anne Sempowski Ward told The Wall Street Journal's Women in the Workplace: Women of Color and the Way Ahead forum. CURiO Brands CEO Anne Sempowski Ward has a simple piece of advice for bosses and colleagues who want to help women of color be successful in their careers: Show them the possibilities "that we don't see."

title: What to Give: Books on Music
summary: John Check on books about Johnny Hodges and Leonard Bernstein, and on two conductors' guides to classical music.. We can neither see music nor taste it, touch nor truly possess it. Yet the best of it moves us profoundly and is passed from age to age. In "For the Love of Music: A Conductor's Guide to the Art of Listening" (Knopf, 210 pages, $25.95), John Mauceri examines the appeal of Western classical music with a winning combination of enthusiasm and authority. A conductor and writer, Mr. Mauceri wants to help others share his wonder. Classical music "creates a parallel universe, one that both feels immutable and is kept dazzlingly alive through its constant reinterpretation by living performers." Listening is the key: closely, repeatedly and imaginatively. Then one comes to perceive how classical music expresses the fluidity of time and creates meaning out of a syntax of pure sound.

title: Bridgewater Makes $1.5 Billion Options Bet on Market Drop
summary: World's largest hedge fund takes on a big bearish trade; founder Dalio says firm's overall position on market isn't negative. Bridgewater Associates LP has bet more than $1 billion that stock markets around the world will fall by March, said people familiar with the matter.

title: British Airways Union Tells Pilots to Settle Costly Pay Dispute
summary: Pilots led their first strike in about 40 years earlier this year after failing to come to an agreement over pay and conditions. LONDON- British Airways ' pilots union has recommended its members settle a long-running dispute over pay, potentially averting further industrial action that has cost the airline millions of dollars and led to the cancellation of hundreds of flights.

title: Psychologist Susan Wheelan Studied Perils of Working in Teams
summary: Temple professor devised methods for resolving squabbles and getting things done. Susan Wheelan devoted much of her career to studying groups of people thrown together to work as teams at businesses and other organizations.

title: Mo Rocca Sees Dead People
summary: In a best-selling book of offbeat obituaries, the humorist and correspondent for 'CBS Sunday Morning' remembers 'people I think of as undervalued stocks'. Mo Rocca has unusual taste in dead people. "I've always been a fan of obituaries," says the humorist and correspondent for " CBS Sunday Morning." He began pursuing his morbid fascination through his hit podcast "Mobituaries," which rigorously and irreverently tells stories about different kinds of death-from "Sammy Davis Jr.: Death of the Entertainer" to "Neanderthals: Death of a Human Species." Mr. Rocca is drawn toward the weird, the offbeat and the overlooked. Unlike flat obituaries, his pieces are remembrances "for someone or something that didn't get the send-off it deserved the first time."

title: U.S. Business Activity Shows Signs of Pickup Against Global Slowdown
summary: New ECB chief Lagarde warns that robust economic growth is 'no longer an absolute certainty'. Business activity in the U.S. is offering signs of a pickup in late 2019, contrasting with more sluggish economic performances in some of the world's other largest economies.

title: Lack of Investor Feedback a Challenge for Black Female Founders
summary: Fundraising is often made tougher because women of color don't get the frank answers other entrepreneurs often do. Black female founders have received far less than 1% of the total technology venture funding raised over the last decade. But the fundraising process is made even more challenging when investors are unwilling to communicate rejection clearly.

title: Your Health Data Isn't as Safe as You Think
summary: Silicon Valley's rush into the health-care business is challenging the antiquated protections of Americans' medical histories. We relinquish all kinds of data to tech companies in exchange for convenience. We hand over our location, our heart rates and even imprints of our eyeballs because we want to order an Uber, track a workout or get through airport security faster. But we expect one thing to be mostly kept private: our medical histories.

title: The Next Time You Trade in Your Car, It Could Be for a Phone
summary: To widen commuting options, new efforts aim to tie together all forms of transit within one mobile app.. On a frosty fall evening a decade ago, a university student named Sonja Heikkilä stood shivering at a dark bus stop in Helsinki. A Finnish engineering student, Ms. Heikkilä found herself wondering why the miracle machine in her purse couldn't orchestrate her commute. Her smartphone, after all, had apps for maps and bus tickets. She could use it to call a cab. All of these were elements of a crosstown ride, but each one stood on its own.

title: Three Men Killed in Fire in Abandoned Queens Home
summary: Victims haven't yet been identified, were likely squatting in the St. Albans home, NYPD says. Three men were killed in a fast-moving fire in an abandoned home in Queens on Thursday night, Fire Department of New York officials said.

title: Fool's Mate or Smooth Move for Chess Broadcaster?
summary: World Chess is making a daring move by asking investors to buy its digital tokens. Talk about a risky gambit.

title: What to Give: Books on Movies
summary: Peter Tonguette on books about Marlon Brando, Preston Sturges and Disney's queens of animation.. More than most industries, the movie business is oddly fixated on failure. Businessmen who prove unsuccessful in running, say, an automobile company are quickly forgotten, but in Hollywood, the stars who have lost their luster and the directors who have misplaced their touch can quickly acquire a mythic quality.

title: What to Give: Books on Art
summary: Cammy Brothers on books about Leonardo, Pablo Picasso and African-American art.. This year marks the 500th anniversary of Leonardo da Vinci's death, and it has resulted in a flurry of exhibitions and publications. Among them, one small book and one very big one, both by scholars who have devoted years of study to Leonardo, stand out. "Leonardo da Vinci: A Life in Drawing" (Rizzoli Electa, 256 pages, $40) by Martin Clayton, is a model of clarity and concision. Leonardo's keen observation of humanity and nature, and his imaginative reach, are most evident in his drawings, and this exhibition catalog offers a way into his world. For the full picture, though, we can now turn to a monumental, four-volume set by Carmen C. Bambach, "Leonardo da Vinci Rediscovered" (Yale, 2,279 pages, $550). With 1,500 illustrations and thorough, scholarly analysis on every aspect of Leonardo's career, the set can be yours for the price of a small luxury handbag.

title: Foot Locker Shares Fall Following Weak Outlook
summary: Despite its clothing-sales struggles, Foot Locker reported healthy third-quarter demand for its sneakers. Shares of Foot Locker Inc. fell on Friday after the sporting-goods retailer gave a disappointing outlook for the holiday-season quarter as it struggles to expand its apparel business.

title: FCC Deals Blow to Huawei and ZTE, Cuts Off Telecom Subsidies
summary: Agency calls the two Chinese telecommunications firms 'national security threat'. WASHINGTON-U.S. regulators labeled two large Chinese telecommunications firms a "national security threat" and voted to ban them from a federal subsidy program, the latest move in a broader push to close them off from U.S. customers.

title: What to Give: Books on Science
summary: Christoph Irmscher on remarkable books about the human body and its anatomy.. In late-15th-century Paris, a clever thief who had been sentenced to die struck an ingenious if not risk-free deal with some equally enterprising doctors: In exchange for his freedom, he would allow his stomach to be cut open so that they could take a peek at a living man's entrails. To the medieval mind, the human body was a puzzle, writes art historian Jack Hartnell in his "Medieval Bodies" (Norton, 346 pages, $29.95), a sumptuously illustrated compendium that includes a picture of the marble effigies of the French king Charles IV and his wife, Jeanne d'Évreux, clutching sacs filled with their own digestive tracts. Wishing to maximize the number of places where people could pray for them, Charles and Jeanne had ordered the royal organs to be buried separately from their other remains. While medieval folks were worried about what lay beneath their skins, they also imagined their bodies as infinitely porous and penetrable, subject to cutting, piercing and bloodletting. When it came to remedies, they mostly improvised: French physician Bernard de Gordon suggested that a catatonic brain could be cured by plucking out the patient's chest hairs and placing a sow and her squealing piglets before him.

title: What to Give: Books on History
summary: Alan Taylor on works by Julia Lovell, Jill Lepore, Mary Fulbrook and Victoria Johnson.. It is the most important book award that you have not heard of: The Cundill History Prize. Created in 2008, the prize originated with F. Peter Cundill (1938-2011), a Canadian philanthropist with a passion for history writing. Based at his alma mater, McGill University, the prize honors the best history written in English during the preceding year. The Cundill favors works that address important topics, offer original research and conclusions, and do so in lucid prose accessible to a wide readership. The winners include Anne Applebaum, Lisa Jardine, Thomas W. Laqueur, Stuart Schwartz and last year, Maya Jasanoff for "The Dawn Watch: Joseph Conrad in a Global World." As chair of the jury for this year's prize, I recommend the three finalists, along with a fourth book, as among the best history books recently published.

title: What to Give: Books on Business
summary: Philip Delves Broughton on memoirs by Marc Benioff, Joe Ricketts, Ben Horowitz and Rick Ross.. The more executives go on about the social value of business, the more I wonder what they've been up to. Marc Benioff, the founder and co-CEO of Salesforce, sells enterprise software. He is rooted in Silicon Valley and at ease with the Davos class. He is a self-made billionaire groovy enough to invite Zen Buddhist monks to his San Francisco headquarters to help his employees act more mindfully. But as his new book makes clear, he thinks it takes a lot more than embracing mindfulness to be an ethical business leader.

title: U.S. Bill Splits Hong Kong Activists and Business Groups
summary: Legislation threatens city's status as financial hub, while offering support for rights advocates. HONG KONG-U.S. legislation that could strip Hong Kong of preferential trade status if Beijing encroaches on the region's political freedoms is dividing protesters who fought for it and business groups that fear it paves the way for economically painful measures.

title: What to Give: Mysteries
summary: Tom Nolan on books about Sherlock Holmes and the collected fiction of James Ellroy.. When it comes to Christmas mystery stories, perhaps the first, and still one of the best, is Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's 1892 Sherlock Holmes tale "The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle." This "wild Christmas goose chase" appears, along with 10 other Holmes tales, in "Being Sherlock: A Sherlockian's Stroll Through the Best Sherlock Holmes Stories" (Lyons, 430 pages, $26.95), compiled by Ashley D. Polasek. The collection is full of lively commentary and pictures of actors who have portrayed Holmes-on stage and screen-from William Gillette to Benedict Cumberbatch. "Being Sherlock" would make a great present for any Baker Street aficionado. "These tales," Ms. Polasek writes of the Holmes canon, "are diverting pop fiction, but . . . they also have considerable literary heft."

title: Trump Says He Would Welcome a Senate Impeachment Trial
summary: President says he would want Adam Schiff as the first witness to testify about the whistleblower. WASHINGTON-President Trump said he would welcome an impeachment trial in the Senate in the hope that Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.), chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, would be called as the first witness to testify about the whistleblower who helped spark the inquiry.

title: Book Review: Learning to Lead
summary: Lessons from the likes of Napoleon Bonaparte, Horatio Nelson, Marcus Aurelius, T.E. Lawrence-and Long John Silver.. From ancient Greeks to the War on Terror, several recent books provide a fresh survey of politico-military leadership through the ages.

title: 'Winterlust' Review: Holidays on Ice
summary: The first recorded snowman in art history was created in 1494 by Michelangelo in Piero de' Medici's courtyard.. One midwinter night, when I was nearly 4 years old, my world was beautifully transformed. My grandmother and I watched through the windows of my home as snowfall erased the road outside and blanketed the landscape. By the next morning, a heavy drift had settled against the door of our house: We were snowed in. Everything was hushed, the telephone line having already been brought down. As space closed around us, time seemed to expand-and then stop. My memories of those days are colored by the shifting snowlight and by my grandmother's calm presence as she taught me to cross-stitch and cooked her way through the contents of our fridge. At no point did I feel alarmed or threatened. When, after four days, a neighbor finally appeared, I was mildly disappointed: The spell had been broken and everything was about to return to normal. Ever since, I have associated snowfall with a benign covering, an erasure of ugliness and the promise and expansion of white space: a blank page.

title: Fed Adds $80.6 Billion to Financial System in Latest Repo Transactions
summary: Central bank also buys $7.50 billion in Treasury bills. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $80.6 billion in temporary liquidity to the financial system on Friday.

title: This Retired Racing Driver's Colorado Estate Has Its Own Car Museum
summary: The 30,000-square-foot showroom is bigger than the home itself. The whole thing is on the market for $19.999 million.. In Evergreen, a tiny Colorado community half an hour outside Denver, sits a massive hilltop estate that could be a car-crazy bachelor's dream come true. Asking $19.999 million, it includes a mansion with a Hugh Hefner-inspired grotto pool and hangar-style "car museum" that can hold over 100 vehicles.

title: What to Give: Books on Nature
summary: Gerard Helferich on works about dogs, elephants and baffling beasts like the platypus.. The platypus is such a weird creature, with its duck-like bill and thick mammalian fur, that when the first pelt arrived in Europe from Australia, in the 1790s, it was thought to be a hoax. In "Consider the Platypus" (Black Dog & Leventhal, 272 pages, $29.99), science journalist Maggie Ryan Sandford examines this curious species and more than 40 others of particular interest to the study of evolution. Ms. Sandford accords each animal its own dossier, including color illustrations, timelines, text boxes and other graphic elements. In cheery, pun-filled prose, she reviews the physical characteristics of the species, sketches its development and considers the evolutionary lesson it has to teach. One recurring theme is the unlikely similarities between us and our fellow animals. Strange though it may seem, human beings and giraffes (in fact, all mammals except the sloth and the manatee) have seven vertebrae in the neck. Our simplest living relative, it turns out, is probably the Great Barrier Reef demosponge, a creature so simple that it "barely looks like an animal, and it even leaves something to be desired as a sponge." Still, some 70% of the demosponge's genome finds direct parallels in our own. And while we're on the subject, did you know that rodents are our closest non-primate relatives? Our genetic overlap with the humble house mouse, depending on how you measure it, is at least 85%.

title: What to Give: Books on Sports
summary: John Schulian on books saluting the National Football League's 100th anniversary.. My old oaken desk wheezes beneath the weight of five books that salute the National Football League's 100th anniversary. I'm convinced that these potential holiday gifts tip the scales at more than the Minnesota Vikings' Purple People Eaters ever did. But then everything about the pro game is bigger these days, from the size of players pumped up way past 300 pounds to the scope of the league's plans for world domination. The people who create the books are just trying to stay in step. So forget about leaving milk and cookies out for Santa Claus. A truss will do him more good.

title: What to Give: Books on Design
summary: Ann Landi on books about Mary Quant, Herman Miller, midcentury modern and more.. As the Beatles and the Rolling Stones were to music during the "Swinging '60s," so Mary Quant was to women's fashion: a cheeky global pop sensation synonymous with postwar Britain's smashing the boundaries of class. "Mary Quant" (V&A Publishing, 224 pages, $45), the copiously illustrated catalog of an exhibition on view at the Victoria and Albert Museum through Feb. 16, describes the now-85-year-old designer's humble origins in wartime London and her early interest in sketching clothes at Goldsmiths College. There she met her future husband and business partner, the aristocratic Alexander Plunket Greene; they were soon joined by a marketing whiz named Archie McNair, and in 1955 together opened Bazaar, an immediately popular shop in Chelsea. The Quant "look" took shape in the late 1950s and early '60s-youthful, liberated, practical and, most of all, showing a whole lot of leg. If Ms. Quant did not invent the miniskirt, she gave the garment its name, and also pioneered such innovations as patterned tights, hot pants, floppy hats, and dresses modeled on soccer jerseys. Her Ginger Group, a wholesale-company spin-off, offered licensing rights world-wide and led to mass production of Quant designs, making them widely available and affordable. Catalog essays touch on other phenomena of the period that solidified the brand: fashion photographers David Bailey and Norman Parkinson, reedy but glamorous models Jean Shrimpton and Twiggy, and the Vidal Sassoon "five-point" haircut. The designer wanted "fun" above all, and "Mary Quant" vividly captures the high spirits of the age while charting one woman's genius and wide-ranging ambitions.

title: 'The Movie Musical!' Review: That's Entertainment
summary: William Dean Howells complained the public wanted 'a tragedy with a happy ending.' Movie musicals once knew how to give it to them.. Jeanine Basinger is a woman of a certain age-not to put too fine a point on it, my age-and so, like me, grew up as a moviegoer of a kind that no longer exists today. Boys and girls of our generation went to the movies every Saturday afternoon without fail, usually without even checking what was playing. In my neighborhood in Chicago, within walking distance, there were five movie theaters. Each offered a newsreel, coming attractions, a cartoon and two full-length feature films. In winter one went into the movie theater in the bright sunlight of 1 p.m. and emerged into the brisk dark of 5 p.m.

title: 'Time Is Tight' Review: The Guru of Groove
summary: The organ riff in Jones's 1962 hit 'Green Onions' was based on contrapuntal chords borrowed from Bach.. Though the Memphis of the 1960s played a pivotal part in the country's civil-rights struggles and musical breakthroughs, perhaps the only memoirist of color to live through the era and document how it felt is the musician Booker T. Jones. "You take on a smallness of stature," he writes in "Time Is Tight: My Life, Note by Note," "an unwillingness to overcome obstacles. Worse than fear, because you can't justify your existence, death bears little consequence."

title: 'American Science Fiction' Review: We Are Stardust, We Are Golden
summary: A boxed set brings together eight classic novels from the 1960s, by masters such Roger Zelazny, Samuel R. Delany and Joanna Russ.. In a letter to Nathaniel Hawthorne, Herman Melville bragged of his belief in a "ruthless democracy" that "boldly declares that a thief in prison is as honorable a personage as Gen. George Washington. This is ludicrous. But Truth is the silliest thing under the sun." Melville, it so happens, was the first author to be published by Library of America when, in 1982, it began its project of preserving American classics (Hawthorne was second), and certainly in recent years the series has been guided by his creed of unconditional democracy, expanding to include genre writers such as Elmore Leonard and Madeleine L'Engle, and producing anthologies of horror stories, crime noir and even musical theater.

title: Beyond Prosecco: The Best Bubblies From the Boot
summary: Italy's finest sparkling wines continue to be eclipsed stateside by the ever popular Prosecco. Here are the under-the-radar bottles savvy oenophiles should be seeking out. THE WORLD of Italian sparkling wine can be divided into three parts: Prosecco, Lambrusco and Everything Else. Or so seems to be the perception of many oenophiles. And yet Everything Else happens to contain some of Italy's best sparkling wines: the Champagne-method (or, in this context, Metodo Classico) wines from Franciacorta in Lombardy, Trentodoc in Trentino and Alta Langa in Piedmont. After tasting a dozen examples in recent weeks, I wondered why more drinkers aren't seeking them out.

title: The Common Forces Propelling the New Popular Revolts
summary: Uprisings from Chile to Iraq show the perils of inequality and the pull of national identity. Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina" principle-"All happy families are alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way"-seems on the surface the right way to think about the political unrest sweeping much of the world as 2019 draws to a close. On almost every continent, from Chile and Bolivia to France to Hong Kong to Lebanon, Iraq, Sudan, Algeria and elsewhere, cities are aflame and streets are thronged with protesters. Governments have been toppled, and even where the authorities have prevailed so far, there's a fragility that betokens a larger uncertainty.

title: Love and Basketball
summary: A posthumously published book recognizes the life's work of Maryland-D.C. sportswriter John McNamara-and the determination of his wife Andrea Chamblee. John McNamara loved basketball. He loved the shiny Top 10 showdowns that everyone loved, but also the smaller school contests very few people cared to watch. He loved the forgotten side characters as much as the superstars; how a box score told only one part of the story; how legends of the game could be shaped in empty gyms and concrete playgrounds.
